other (Plate V Fig 1); an inosculation of two columns not being
infrequent, and more rarely a fusion of two columns into one. All
these features of structure presented by the shell are beautifully
displayed by the animal (Plate I, Fig 4); the columns of sarcode
(<u>cc, c'c'</u>) exhibiting the imperfect transverse segmental division, the not
infrequent inosculation, and the occasional fusion which
we have seen to exist in the cavities which they occupy. At
thier upper and lower extremities, they unite with the horizontal
bands (<u>bb',bb')</u> which pass continuously round, in each zone, between the
intermediate and the supericial layers.

30  Save in the case of such accidental inosculations as
those just noticed <s>,</s> which are indicated in such sections as
that represented in <s>(</s> Plate VI, Fig 3, by the irregularly disposed
apertures, <u>h,h</u>) no other lateral communication seems to exist between the
contiguous cells of the same zone, than that which is established by
the annular stolons just mentioned. The cells of the successive
zones communicate with each other, however, as in the simple
type previously described (§17); but with a curious modification.
